question: [File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Language version attack] Does LanguageVersion::latest_stable() (line 157) properly enforce language feature restrictions, or can tests enable experimental features that bypass security checks in the Move VM? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Panic handling] Does build_and_report_v2_driver() on line 164 properly handle compilation errors, or does the unwrap() cause a panic that crashes the entire test suite without reporting which test or file caused the failure? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Resource exhaustion] Can an attacker provide malicious Move source files that cause exponential compilation time in build_and_report_v2_driver(), leading to DoS during test execution? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Memory leak] If construct_test_plan() returns None (line 165), does the function properly clean up the allocated files and units, or could repeated compilation failures cause memory leaks? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Type confusion] Can an attacker craft Move code that passes compilation but creates invalid TestPlan structures, causing type confusion or memory corruption when tests are executed? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Named address injection] On line 159, does the format string '{}={}' for named_address_mapping properly escape special characters, or can an attacker inject malicious compiler directives through address names or values? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Path validation bypass] Are source_files and dependencies parameters validated before being passed to move_compiler_v2::Options (lines 154-155), or can attackers bypass filesystem restrictions through compiler option manipulation? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Test code injection] Does compile_test_code: true (line 152) properly isolate test code from production code, or can malicious tests access or modify production Move modules during compilation? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: compile_to_test_plan()] [Return value safety] On line 168, does map() properly handle the case where test_plan is Some but files/units are corrupt, potentially returning a TestPlan with mismatched metadata? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_test_plan()] [Double compilation] Does calling compile_to_test_plan() twice (lines 177 and 179) with different source_files create a risk of test plan corruption if the same module is defined in both deps and sources? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_test_plan()] [Module shadowing] Can the module_info.extend() call on line 180 allow dependency modules to shadow or override source modules, causing tests to execute against wrong implementations? (Critical)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_test_plan()] [File path collision] Does files.extend() on line 181 check for duplicate file paths between dependencies and sources, or could file path collisions cause incorrect source mapping during error reporting? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_test_plan()] [Error propagation] If the first compile_to_test_plan() call (line 177) succeeds but the second (line 179) fails, does the function properly clean up partial state, or could this cause memory leaks or dangling references? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_test_plan()] [Ownership confusion] After extracting files and module_info from the first TestPlan (line 177), are these structures properly owned by the second TestPlan, or could there be use-after-free issues during test execution? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_test_plan()] [Circular dependencies] If dep_files and source_files reference each other circularly, can this cause infinite recursion or stack overflow during the two compilation passes? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: build_test_plan()] [Determinism violation] Does the extend() operation on module_info preserve deterministic ordering, or could non-deterministic HashMap/BTreeMap iteration cause different test execution orders across runs? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Mutex poisoning] If a panic occurs while writing to shared_writer (line 197), does the Mutex become poisoned, causing all subsequent lock attempts to fail and preventing test result reporting? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Race condition] Can concurrent writes to shared_writer from multiple test threads (line 204) cause interleaved output or corrupted test result reporting due to non-atomic write operations? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Deadlock risk] If TestRunner::run() on line 232 attempts to acquire shared_writer while another thread holds it, could this cause a deadlock that hangs the entire test suite indefinitely? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Resource leak] If TestRunner::new() fails on line 215, does the function properly clean up native_function_table and genesis_state, or could this cause memory leaks in long-running test processes? (Low)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Panic on unwrap] Does the unwrap() call on line 226 after TestRunner::new() properly handle initialization failures, or could this cause uncontrolled panics that crash validator nodes during test execution? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Filter bypass] Can the filter string on line 228-230 be crafted to bypass test filtering and execute malicious tests that should be excluded (e.g., tests marked as unsafe or experimental)? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Panic on unwrap] Does the unwrap() on line 232 after test_runner.run() propagate test execution errors, or could this cause silent failures where critical test failures are not reported? (High)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [State corruption] If report_statistics() (line 234) or report_goldens() (line 238) fail with I/O errors, does this corrupt the test_results state or cause subsequent summarize() to report incorrect pass/fail status? (Medium)

[File: third_party/move/tools/move-unit-test/src/lib.rs] [Function: run_and_report_unit_tests()] [Panic on unwrap] Can the into_inner().unwrap() calls on lines 211 and 243 panic if the Mutex is poisoned, causing test result data loss or preventing proper cleanup of test resources? (Medium)
